data.title: ECONNRESET on last build-step
data.body:
Both
```
gulp vscode-darwin-min --max_old_space_size=4096
```
and
```
gulp vscode-darwin --max_old_space_size=4096
```

lead to

```
[01:29:36] Starting 'vscode-darwin-min'...
stream.js:74
      throw er; // Unhandled stream error in pipe.
      ^

Error: connect ECONNRESET 191.238.172.191:443
    at Object.exports._errnoException (util.js:1022:11)
    at exports._exceptionWithHostPort (util.js:1045:20)
    at TCPConnectWrap.afterConnect [as oncomplete] (net.js:1087:14)
```

I had no problem building before `1.13`, not sure what's changed build-wise. I see that the IP resolves to `vsassets.io`, but again, I'm not sure why and where the request is being made.

`macOS 10.12.4` with `vscode/release/1.13`

data.title: Test: protocol autodetection when node is put into debug mode late
data.body:
Test for #25036 

Complexity: 2

- [x] Windows - @isidorn
- [x] OS X - @rebornix
- [x] Linux - @mjbvz 

If node is not started in debug mode, it is still possible to attach VS Code node-debug to it. For this the process ID is needed and node-debug will send a SIGUSR1 signal (on Windows some other magic) to a process with the given ID.

With the advent of node v8.0 things got a bit complicated because the mechanism described above will make node.js versions >= v8.0 support the "inspector" protocol, whereas older versions of node support the "legacy" protocol.
Instead of probing for the protocol on the possible debug ports (and running the risk of confusing node.js with this), VS Code uses OS utilities (nestat or lsof) to detect the open ports of the node.js process and infers the supported protocol from this.

For verification run this program 
```js
let i = 0;
setInterval(() => {
    console.log("tick " + i++);
}, 1000);

```
on two node versions: one < 8.0 and one >= 8.0.
Make sure that you can attach the VS Code node debugger in both cases with the following launch config:
```json
	{
		"type": "node",
		"request": "attach",
		"name": "Attach via Process ID",
		"processId": "${command:PickProcess}"
	}
```

data.title: Test: Improved terminal selection
data.body:
Test for #9761. #9958, #15199

Complexity: 4

- [x] Linux - @joaomoreno  
- [x] macOS - @jrieken 
- [x] Windows - @ramya-rao-a 

Terminal selection has been completely reimplemented in this release, previously it relied on the standard Chromium web selection which featured many shortcomings with all the various tricks that were used to get a terminal working in a browser efficiently. This means that things that you may take for granted like word selection on double click+drag or line selection on triple click have been handled explicitly.

Here are some of the things that need to be tested:

- Copy works using various types of selections
  - Single click and drag
  - Double click
  - Double click and drag
  - Triple click
  - Triple click and drag
  - Selection using the mouse wheel to scroll the viewport
  - Select all (via command palette or cmd+a on macOS)
  - Select all and copy while the command is streaming in input and the buffer is being trimmed (when there are more lines than `terminal.integrated.scrollback`)
- Paste
- Selection works fine when starting from a link
- Selection works fine when starting from text in the prompt
- Selection is retained when the viewport is scrolled or a new command is run
- Selection is drawn in the correct position with various `window.zoomLevel` values and monospace fonts
- Context menu actions work (Copy, Paste, Select All)
- Whitespace padding on the right of text should never be copied to the clipboard
  - Copying the whitespace padding does does nothing
  - Copying whitespace on the left or right of a word is retained 
- Linux specific:
  - Select something outside of VS Code and middle click to paste the selection
  - Select something in the VS Code editor and middle click to paste the selection
  - Select in the VS Code terminal and middle click to paste the selection
  - The new selection logic should be disabled when `tmux` is launched with mouse mode set
- macOS specific:
  - The new selection logic should be disabled when `tmux` is launched with mouse mode set

xterm.js PR: https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/pull/670

data.title: Select all should be in the terminal context menu
Feature Request: Enable Background Styling With Themes For Template Strings
data.body:
I'm currently experimenting on a modified syntax file for Javascript / Typescript where we can add a comment before or after a string to turn on syntax highlighting on template string for a specified syntax, ie, SQL, HTML, etc.

So far its been successful and I could see this be useful for other languages as well, ie, Markdown in a Python template string, and so on...

This is great, however, with syntax highlighting for template strings, in some context it becomes difficult to know where a template string begins or ends as all the text isn't the same color anymore. This could be easily addressed with background colors.

The issue is that VS Code doesn't allow background styling, making it difficult to see where a template string starts or ends.

data.title: Test: Find in terminal
data.body:
Test for #15198

Complexity: 2

- [x] Linux - @mjbvz    
- [x] macOS - @egamma 
- [x] Windows - @gregvanl 

The terminal now features a find widget which can be accessed via ctrl+f or cmd+f if the terminal is focused. It should work very similar to the editor find widget just with less capabilities and tuned for use in the terminal.

Find next/previous will search either from the top row of the viewport, or from the selection if there is one. Note that the regular selection is used to present the search result, not a special "find selection" like in the editor.

See known issues/improvements in #28768

data.title: Test: New multi-root aware file watcher
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28947

Complexity: 5

- [x] Linux 64 Bits - @isidorn    
  - [x] Opened tab is updated when modified outside of VS Code
  - [x] Explorer updates when file events occur outside of VS Code (eg. another editor/`git checkout`)
  - [x] Adding/removing root folders does not confuse the watcher and events are reported for newly added folders (note: when you transition back to single root, we stop using NSFW unless the `files.useExperimentalFileWatcher` is set to `true`)
  - [x] Supports `files.watcherExclude` setting in different folders to ignore events
  - [x] Symlinks are followed (e.g. you get file events for symlinked folder contents)
  - [x] Prevents circular symlinks (e.g. no endless loop when you have this on disk)
  - [x] Supports large folders - what happens when the file watch limit is hit and you're hit with an `ENOSPC`? (see [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux#_error-enospc) for how to configure this)
  - [x] Supports remote file systems (e.g. use Parallels to see folders from Windows and/or macOS and verify events are forwarded through)
- [x] Linux 32 Bits - @joaomoreno    
  - [x] Opened tab is updated when modified outside of VS Code
  - [x] Explorer updates when file events occur outside of VS Code (eg. another editor/`git checkout`)
  - [x] Adding/removing root folders does not confuse the watcher and events are reported for newly added folders (note: when you transition back to single root, we stop using NSFW unless the `files.useExperimentalFileWatcher` is set to `true`)
  - [x] Supports `files.watcherExclude` setting in different folders to ignore events
  - [x] Symlinks are followed (e.g. you get file events for symlinked folder contents)
  - [x] Prevents circular symlinks (e.g. no endless loop when you have this on disk)
  - [x] Supports large folders - what happens when the file watch limit is hit and you're hit with an `ENOSPC`? (see [here](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/linux#_error-enospc) for how to configure this)
  - [x] Supports remote file systems (e.g. use Parallels to see folders from Windows and/or macOS and verify events are forwarded through) 
- [x] macOS - @sandy081 
  - [x] Opened tab is updated when modified outside of VS Code
  - [x] Explorer updates when file events occur outside of VS Code (eg. another editor/`git checkout`)
  - [x] Adding/removing root folders does not confuse the watcher and events are reported for newly added folders (note: when you transition back to single root, we stop using NSFW unless the `files.useExperimentalFileWatcher` is set to `true`)
  - [x] Supports `files.watcherExclude` setting in different folders to ignore events
  - [x] Symlinks are followed (e.g. you get file events for symlinked folder contents)
  - [x] Prevents circular symlinks (e.g. no endless loop when you have this on disk)
  - [x] Supports folders with unicode characters in their name (see https://github.com/nodejs/node/issues/2165 for the glory details on unicode normalization on HFS and node)
  - [x] Supports opening paths with wrong casing - eg. `/foo` is on disk but `/FOO` is the folder that is opened (via the command line) and file events continue to work
  - [x] Supports remote file systems (e.g. use Parallels to see folders from Windows and/or Linux and verify events are forwarded through)
- [x] Windows - @mjbvz    
  - [x] Opened tab is updated when modified outside of VS Code
  - [x] Explorer updates when file events occur outside of VS Code (eg. another editor/`git checkout`)
  - [x] Adding/removing root folders does not confuse the watcher and events are reported for newly added folders (note: when you transition back to single root, we stop using NSFW unless the `files.useExperimentalFileWatcher` is set to `true`)
  - [x] Supports `files.watcherExclude` setting in different folders to ignore events
  - [x] Symlinks are followed (e.g. you get file events for symlinked folder contents)
  - [x] Prevents circular symlinks (e.g. no endless loop when you have this on disk)
  - [x] Supports virtual drives (setup via `subst` command)
  - [x] Supports UNC mounted filesystems (there is a notation to do this via localhost: `\\localhost\c$\my_dir`)
  - [x] Supports OneDrive folders
  - [x] Briefly verify watcher supports Windows 7
  - [x] Supports opening paths with wrong casing - eg. `/foo` is on disk but `/FOO` is the folder that is opened (via the command line) and file events continue to work
  - [x] Supports remote file systems (e.g. use Parallels to see folders from macOS and/or Linux and verify events are forwarded through)

https://github.com/Axosoft/nsfw has been introduced behind a setting that allows file watching to use the same underlying library for all OS's as well as being multi-root aware. The file watcher can be enabled by using the setting `"files.useExperimentalFileWatcher": true`, or by just opening multiple folders.

The major test cases are highlighted above, make sure you refresh as you're checking a checkbox off to prevent update conflicts. Most of which will involve modifying a file and observing the file event propagates.

You can add a multi-root folder by opening a folder in VS Code and then using the `File: Add Root Folder...` command. This adds the relevant settings to your user settings. Also be sure to launch VS Code using `code-insiders --verbose` to get file watcher events in the devtools console, this will help verify events are firing correctly and will be very valuable in debugging issues. To verify you are using the new watcher, check the console for this entry:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/900690/27572043-e3f2a324-5b09-11e7-95d1-bf3cb219a8d2.png)

data.title: Test: Windows executables are found even if no extension is specified
data.body:
Test for https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28100#issuecomment-311110422

Complexity: 1

- [x] Windows - @michelkaporin    

On Windows it was always necessary to include the correct extension in the `runtimeExecutable` path which lead to this laborious cross platform solution:
 ```json
    "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/nodemon"
    "windows": {
        "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/nodemon.cmd"
    }
```

With the [sub-feature](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28100#issuecomment-311110422) it should no longer be necessary to include the extension in the path (which makes the path portable).

Verify on Windows that a `runtimeExecutable` that points to `${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/xxx` works even if the real Windows executable is `xxx.cmd`, `xxx.exe`, etc. The full list of extensions comes from the `PATHEXT` env var.

Please verify for both legacy and inspector protocols

data.title: Test proposed multi root workspace API
data.body:

Complexity: 2

- [x] Any OS - @mjbvz 

We have added some [API](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28526#issuecomment-310022188) to expose multiple root folders. Try to program against it and see if there is something missing. Also make sure proposed API cannot be used unless the extension opt's in to using proposed API. FYI  - To test proposed API, generate a new extension and copy the `vscode.proposed.d.ts` file into your workspace.

data.title: Test Settings
data.body:
Test for #28538 

- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer     
- [x] OS X - @weinand 
- [x] Linux - @Lixire 

Complexity: 4

## No Workspace

- Settings are read and applied from Default / User settings. Make sure user settings override defaults.
- Update User settings and verify the update.
- Update settings using User actions like `Toggling Sidebar Visibility` and verify updates
- Write a simple extension and verify 
 --  Settings are read and inspected (Default / User) correctly
 -- Settings can be update correctly. Writing into workspace context should fail.

## Single root Workspace

- Settings are read and applied from Default / User / Workspace settings. Make sure workspace settings override user settings and default settings.
- Update User settings and Workspace settings and verify the updates.
- Update settings using User actions and verify updates
-- Have `files.associations` setting in Workspace scope and try to update the file association using the language mode on the status bar. Verify workspace setting is updated.
- Write a simple extension and verify
-- Settings are read and inspected (Default / User / Workspace) correctly
-- Settings can be update correctly

## Multi root Workspace

- Please go through the [comment](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28538#issuecomment-310613318) to know how Settings in multi-root workspace works

In brief, currently supported Folder scoped settings
```
editor.*
files.exclude
files.trimTrailingWhitespace
files.insertFinalNewLine
files.encoding
files.autoGuessEncoding
files.watcherExclude
search.exclude
```
Rest are Workspace scoped settings.

Source of Settings are 
- Defaults come from Default settings
- User settings come from User settings file
- Workspace settings come from Settings file of first root folder excluding Folder scoped settings
- Folder settings come from Settings file of root folders excluding Workspace scoped settings.

Verify:

- Default setting is applied to all folders unless overridden
- User setting is applied to all folders unless overridden
- Workspace setting is applied to all folders unless overridden
- Folder settings are applied only to themseleves.
- Write a simple extension which is multi root aware
  - Copy [vscode.proposed.d.ts](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/vscode.proposed.d.ts) into your extension.
  - Enable your extension to use proposed api by adding `"enableProposedApi": true` to `package.json` 
  - Use the proposed API `workspace.getConfiguration2()`to read settings. Make sure you are able to get and inspect settings from different folders. 
- Try to pass a resource belongs/ do not belongs to one of the root folders to the above API and verify getting and inspecting configuration.

**NOTE:** If the root folder does not have a `.vscode` folder and `settings.json` file under it, you have to manually create them so that you can add folder settings.

data.title: Remove translate3d from list and use css will-change property
Multi root: language servers adoption
data.body:
We need to decide how multi root surfaces for language servers and the LSP. This includes:
* access to the root paths (read, write?)
* access to folder scoped settings

We should validate our approach by adopting folder based settings for the extensions we ship with (e.g. CSS).

data.title: UX: finalize multi root SCM design
data.body: We need to make SCM UX fit for multi root and should agree on the visual solution.

data.title: Multi root: indicate unsupported settings on a folder level visually
data.body: E.g. by graying them out. I would not show a warning so that people are not accidentally removing a setting that is still valid when opening the folder alone.

data.title: Syntax highlighting fails when a html tag is inside a data attribute
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z) - OS Version: Linux x64 4.8.0-56-generic - Extensions: |Extension|Author|Version| |---|---|---| |theme-dracula|dracula-theme|2.1.2| |hopscotch|idleberg|0.1.4| --- Steps to Reproduce: 1. Make a new html document 2. Paste the following html code into the editor ```

This is a paragraph

This is also a paragraph

``` ![vs-code-screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/ObCQoRa.png) You can see from the image above that syntax does not highlight correctly when you have have an html tag inside a data attribute. This is a valid statement as per the [HTML 5 reference: ](http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#attributes) > Except where otherwise specified, attributes on HTML elements may have any string value, including the empty string. Except where explicitly stated, there is no restriction on what text can be specified in such attributes. It works when the charectars are escaped like: ``

data.title: vscode delete ftp file when dragging ftp file onto it and vscode would not open that file.
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 (1703)

VS Code will automatically delete ftp file when I drag a ftp file onto VS Code.
Some other text editor like notepad++ does not allow you to drag a ftp file onto it. However, vscode does, it would not open that file but delete it.How shocking, it would ruin my day!

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a ftp with username and password in windows explorer.
2. Drag a html file on ftp onto vscode.
3. The ftp file will disappear. And vscode would not open that file.

data.title: Support files.association as folder setting

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: There is some cleanup needed in order to support `files.association` on a per-folder scope. Today we have a static registry in base that receives the association. We should maybe introduce a service for this that is also aware of multi-root (= making `files.association` a folder setting).
